Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with diabetes mellitus and hypertension who presented after experiencing a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. The patient was found unresponsive and in VF arrest, and was shocked once with conversion to sinus tachycardia. 

The patient has been initiated on the Arctic Sun cooling protocol for therapeutic hypothermia following the VF arrest. He received 100mg IV lidocaine and amiodarone 150mg bolus, and is currently being administered amiodarone at 1mg/hr. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 33.2°C (91.8°F), heart rate of 57 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 98/58mmHg to 133/64mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood glucose levels, elevated troponin-T levels, and abnormal liver function tests. 

The assessment and plan include rhythm management, cooling protocol, cardiac arrest team consult, EEG with neuro input, sedation with propofol, continuation of amiodarone, q6 hour labs and coags per cooling protocol, head CT to rule out bleed, monitoring of mean arterial pressure (MAP) between 60-70, trending central venous pressure (CVP), transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), electrocardiogram (ECG), chest X-ray (CXR), placement of arterial line and central venous line, and consideration of cardiac catheterization if signs of ischemia are present. 

The patient's respiratory failure is being managed with mechanical ventilation and a plan to repeat CXR, sedation according to cooling protocol, arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, and a-line placement. 

There is also a mention of unclear coronary artery disease, pulmonary edema, lower extremity edema, and leukocytosis. The patient's history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension is noted. 

Prophylactic measures include deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis with heparin, bowel regimen as needed, and stress ulcer prophylaxis. 

The patient's disposition is currently in the critical care unit (CCU).
